awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Connecting linguistic and perceptual development through symmetry
awd_abstract_narration:
The extent of children's knowledge of language at school entry predicts their later academic success, even for those disciplines not commonly associated with language skills, such as science and mathematics. For example, teachers tell children that “two and two is equal to four”, and that “the earth is similar to (or “is like”) a ball”.  Our ultimate understanding of mathematical symbols and their combination are supported by language, through words and their syntactic combination. This research examines how children come to understand the abstract meaning of logical words such as “equal”, “similar”, and “and”. How do children learn that if X is similar to Y, Y must be similar to X? These examples have in common the key concept that is the focus of the planned research, the concept of symmetry – a central idea in perception, language and thought. Symmetry is a relation that remains the same even when reversed logically or physically. Thus, if X equals Y, Y must equal X, and if the button matches the shirt, so must the shirt match the button. Symmetry seems an exotic topic but in fact is foundational in reasoning, geometry, algebra, biology, and physics, and is threaded through the vocabulary, including nouns (“cousin”), verbs (“meet”), and adjectives (“similar”). Despite the ubiquity of symmetry in language and its formative connection to STEM, little is known about how preschoolers acquire an understanding of symmetrical words, or how they perceive symmetrical interactions. Answering these questions will help explain children’s differences in language abilities and STEM-related learning. 

All experiments examine how humans perceive, think and/or communicate about symmetry at different stages of development, from infancy to adulthood. Most employ real-time measures, in which eye gaze is recorded as participants hear speech describing scenes of individuals engaged in (a-)symmetrical interactions. A moment-by-moment record is obtained for how participants link scene and syntax and engage in learning of words with potentially (a-)symmetrical meanings. Study 1 examines whether preverbal infants distinguish between perceptually symmetrical vs. asymmetrical interactions, and how older children link perception to abstract symmetry. Study 2 examines when children come to have an adult understanding of symmetrical vs. asymmetrical syntax in language. Study 3 examines how learners combine evidence about symmetrical relations from perceptual and linguistic input. Research incorporates significant education and outreach: undergraduates are involved in research and trained in eye-tracking; research occurs at museums and local preschools, where parents learn about developmental research, its importance, and outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated how young children learn words and sentence structures that are essential for logical reasoning -- a critical foundation for success in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Specifically, the research focused on how children acquire words that express the concept of symmetry, a fundamental idea in perception, language, and thought. Symmetry describes relationships where if something is true in one direction, it must also be true in the reverse. For example, if one object matches another (e.g., a button matches a shirt), the reverse must also be true: the shirt matches the button. Symmetrical relationships are universal across languages and are expressed through a variety of words, such as nouns (e.g., "cousin"), verbs (e.g., "meet", "marry"), and adjectives (e.g., "similar"). Learning these words is key for children to communicate relationships that follow the logic of symmetry, which in turn forms the basis for understanding broader concepts like equality, similarity, and mutual effects later in life.

Research under this grant revealed that humans have an abstract understanding of symmetry that can be accessed through both visual perception and language. In one set of studies, human participants matched visual images -- some possessing visual symmetry and some not -- with English words that had corresponding symmetrical and non-symmetrical meanings. Results showed participants preferred to assign words like "meet" (which describe symmetrical relationships) to symmetrical images, and words like "greet" (which describe non-symmetrical relationships) to non-symmetrical images, even though the images themselves had no direct connection to the meanings of the words. Remarkably, we also observed these phenomena when we asked hearing people to "translate" videos of American Sign Language (ASL) to English, despite having no prior knowledge of sign language. They associated symmetrical two-handed ASL signs with symmetrical English verbs and non-symmetrical two-handed signs with non-symmetrical verbs. These findings suggest that humans possess a deeply rooted, abstract concept of symmetry that bridges perception and language. More broadly, this research highlights the rich and structured connections between how we think and how we use language.

Other studies examined how children learn the meaning of symmetrical and non-symmetrical terms in their language. In one set of studies, children were exposed to a novel verb (e.g., "blicking") in a conversation among adults, who used it in grammatical contexts that either supported a symmetrical or non-symmetrical meaning of this word. The children then had to guess the meaning of the word by matching it to visual actions. These studies are still on-going but results suggest that children from a wide range of ages (3 to 9 years) appreciate the grammatical cues to symmetrical and non-symmetrical meaning.

This project used a variety of methods to study how language is understood and processed in real time. One key approach involved tracking eye movements as children and adults listened to speech describing objects or events in their visual surroundings. By analyzing where people looked as they heard specific words or phrases, findings revealed how language and visual perception work together. Additionally, the team developed internet-based tools to record the direction of participants' gaze over webcams, enabling data collection from children and adults when in-person studies were not feasible.

The findings from this research have been distributed through peer-reviewed journal articles, presentations at major professional conferences, and invited talks at universities. The findings have implications for our understanding of cognitive development, word learning, and linguistics. They support the idea that even from infancy, humans perceive the world in ways that highlight spatial relationships and the structure of events. This early ability to extract structure plays a crucial role in the rapid learning of abstract, relational meanings in language. The research also provides new insights into how learning grammar connects with understanding the meanings of words and sentences, shedding light on the interplay between language and thought.

Throughout the project, its activities have had a meaningful impact on the training and development of students and postdoctoral researchers, including those from underrepresented groups. Undergraduate and graduate students received mentorship in all aspects of the scientific process, including critically evaluating published research, designing experiments to test hypotheses, collecting data from adults and young children, analyzing results, and presenting findings. The project involved the mentoring of three Ph.D. students (two in Psychology and one in Linguistics), two predoctoral researchers, and two postdoctoral trainees. Many of these young researchers also gained valuable experience in mentoring others by helping to supervise undergraduate students involved in the research, fostering the next generation of scientists and scholars.
